bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of Document.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image.

keywords.term: Denning, J. Henry Mason, William Miller, John F. Nordstrom, Charles W. Lewis, James Hamilton Jacobs, Orange Spencer, W. C. McBride, W. P. Ellanerth, P. C. Hart, John B. Calhoun, C. V. Willard, Rufus S. Marion, A. B. Bories, Emil McElroy, James F. Ayres, A. Reeves Walthew, H. M. Hanford, C. H. Ashley, M Moors, A. N. Van de Vanter, A. T. Van de Vanter, A. D. McKenney, James H. Owrigher, B.
King County, Washington Washington D.C. Seattle, Washington

org.orgName: United States Circuit Court Northern Division

div1.p: IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES FOR THE DISTRICT
In the matter of the Application of Charles W. Nordstrom, for the Writ of Habeas Corpus, Appearing by his next friend, J. Henry Denning
PETITION FOR WRIT OF HABEAS CORPUS
To the Honorable Judge of the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Washington, Northern Division:-
Your petitioner for relief by habeas corpus and for writ therein most respectfully to the court, that,
Your petitioner J. Henry Denning avers that he is the friend of the said Charles W Nordstrom in whose behafl he petitions for relief in habeas Corpus and for a writ of habeas corpus herein.

That the said Charles W. Nordstrom is a citizen of the United States and a resident of the State of Washington, and is at present confined in the county jail of King County, State of Washington, under an alleged conviction of muder had in the Superior Court of the State of Washington for King County, on April 2, 1892, and thereafter various proceedings were had and judgement and final sentence of death taken had against said Charles W. Nordstrom by the said Superior Court of the State of Washington.

And that they said Nordstrom was sentenced to death and to be excecuted by the sheriff of said King County, and that subsequently to-wit, on the day of 189, the said Charles W. Nordstrom sued out a writ of habeas corpus before the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Washington, Northern Division, claiming relief thereunder; saild reflief being denied by the said Circuit Court, whereupon and thereafter said petitioner appealed said Habeas Corpus proceeding to the Supreme Court of the United States; said Sureme Court of the United States did on the day of 189, dismiss the petition upon the ground that the matter was not complete enough in the details of the pleading, in failing to set out with proper certainty and preciseness the exact grounds upon which the petitioner rested his contentions embracing the attempt to deprive petitioner of his life without due process of law, particularly, in that he failed to annex a copy of the indictment or information and to set out the verdct in the case, both of which were subjects of complaint; that thereafter the said court duly dismissed said petition and con- firmed the order of the Circuit Court of the United States for the State of Washington, and sent down to said Circuit Court of the United States for the State of Washington its mandate on or about the 8th day of March, 1899.

That said mandate of the Supreme Court of the United States specifically provided that the said cause of said petitioner was returned to the said Circuit Court of the United States for further proceedings therein to be had, to-wit, to be had in the Circuit Court of the United States for the State of Washington according to the laws of the United States and according to justice on the permises.

That thereafter, to-wit, on the 15th day of May, 1899, the said Superior Court of the State of Washington for King County assumed to take jurisdiction of the petitioner befire any final judgment had been made by the said Circuit Court of the United States for the State of Washington upon said petition and in accordance with the mandate of the Supreme Court of the United States, and without any order having been made by said Circuit Court of the United States, or by any proper order whatsoever in the premises either transferrng the said cause to the said Superior Court of the State of Washington, or releasing and relieving itself of jurisdiction of said peitioner Charles W. Nordstrom

That the said petitioner Charles W. Nordstrom by his friend duly made objection to the Superior Court of the State of Washington for King COunty, to-wit, the Hon. Orange Jacobs, Judge, taking jurisdic- tion therein in anywise whatsoever, for that, to-wit, the said petition- er had the right to proceed n the said United States Circuit by appro- priate amendment amendng his petition to conform to the opinion of the Supreme Court of the United States, in the cause given and rendered in that certain case, entitled, Charles W. Nordstrom v. The State of Washington, based upon the opinion and reasons of that other certain case of Carner v. State of Washington, both petitions being similar in letter, words, paragraph and subject matter.

That said Superior Court of the State of Washington for King County assumed to take jurisdiction over the objections of said petitioner, and did proceed, notwithstanding, to exercise said jurisdiction to the exlusion of the said Circuit Court of the United States against the objection and protest of said petitioner and his friend, to which due exception was taken, which exception was allowed and preserved in the record of said cause.

The petitioner informed the court by affidavit and by due presen- tation of the record that sad question of said petitioner's federal rights in the Federal Court was still undisposed of, which said affidavit was duly filed and duly presented before the said Hon. Orange Jacobs, Judge of the said Superior Court of the State of Washington for King County, and the said federal question was therein fully stated, wholly and completely, as more fully appears by reference to the record on file in the Superior Court of the State of Washington for King County, which said objection to the said jurisdiction to said jurisdiction were in the words as appears in exhibit "a" to this peition, which exhibit is made a part of this petition for reference.

Your petitioner further alleges that notwithstanding said objec- tion and said question being raised, that said Superior Court of the State of Washington for King County proceeded to take jurisdiction of the person of petutuiner and sentence him to death, to-wit, to die on the 11th day of August 1899, to be hanged by the sheriff of said King County; that from said conduct and action of said Judge of the Superior Court of the State of Washington for King County said petitioner did duly appeal to the Supreme Court of the State of Washing- ton claiming relief and exemption upon his said ground of his federal rights and previleges as therein set fort; that the Supreme Court of the State of Washington did on the 24th day of July, 1899, deny to the said petitioner relief, and did decide the said federal question and conention against the interests of said pettioner and adverse to his contention, and did refuse the relief prayed for, and did affirm the condcut and action of the said Superior Court, to-wit, the judgement of the said Hon. Orange Jacobs in overrulung the obections of said petitioner to the jurisdiction of his court, and did overrule and deny petitioner's petition for relief upon the ground that under the federak kaw and the Consitution of the united States that said Auperior Court had no jurisdiction of the cause and of the petitioner, for that, to-wit, the said Circuit Court of the United States for the State of Washington alone and only held and had jurisdiction of the Retitioner in anywise whatsoever any proceeding whatsoever authoriaing the State court to take jurisdiction of the person of the said Charles W. Nordstrom in anywise whatsoever.

The the said Supreme Court of the State of Washington in so de- ciding against the contention and claim of right of said petitioner denied him his rights under the Constituion and laws of the United States, and decided contrary to petitioner's rights under the con- stitution of the United States, and against the laws of the United States, and in violation of the laws of the United States and to the detriment of petitioner's interests and against the life of petitioner and contrary to the Constitution of the United Stat es and the laws thereunder.

Your petitioner further showeth that previous to the 15th day of May, 1899, to-wit, on March the 18th, 1899, prior to and previous to the Superior Court taking jurisdiction of said Charles W. Nordstrom, Your petitioner J. Henry Denning as the friend of the said Charles W. Nordstrom did duly by affidavit make known to the court a fact which has ever since remained, and is now a factm that the said Charles W. Nordstrom gas subce tge verdict and judgmebt against him, become insane, that he was of unsound mind, that he was demented and crazy, that he was unable to present to the court in his own behalf any fact or factsw which might go to the amelioration of his sentence or the avoidance of the execution thereupon. That he was in such condiction of mind as to be unable to prepare himself for the event of death, and was in such a state of mind as to make the act inhuman that would take his life by process of law or otherwise, that the said Chares W. Nordstro m was wholly irrespnsible in mind, and for a long time prior thereto has been and was then a subject for the insane asylum, being crazy and insane.

That the petitioner did ask that a hearig be had for the said Charles W. Nordstrom, that said hearing be judicial, that said hearing be legal, that petitioner did pettion that all proceedings against the said Charles W. Nordstrom be stayed until such legal hearing could be had, that said Charles W. Nordstrom be permitted such a hearing, and particularly, for such a hearing as would enable him to produce witness- es and those acquainted with his condition by whom it could be demon- strated annd established that he was of such unsound mind as to exempt him from furtherprocess of the law, and to exept him from any other or further process of the courts looking to his inoaroeration as criminal and of taking his life as such.

That said court delined and refused to grant to the said Nordstrom a legal hearing either by jury or by legal comission in open court whereat and at which time the said Nordstrom would have the opportunity through his friend to establish his mental condition. That said peti- tion was sustained by affidavit and by evidence tendered to the court from impartial, reliable, trustworthy, and wholly creditable sources who has knowledge and information absolute as to the condition of the mind of the said Nordstrom, yet, nevertheless and notwithstanding, the said court refused to grant the said Nordstrom an opportunity of presenting witnesses in his behafl through his friend or in anywise in order to establish at a legal hearing in open court or to a jury or before the court upon a trial his real mental condition or to establish his said insanity.

That subsequently the said court nevertheless proceeded upon the statement that the said court was satisfied and did proceed notwith- standing theinformation of the affidavid informing the said courtof the insanity of the said Nordstrom; and your petitioner durther showeth that said affidavid was in nowise denied denied by the said court or the Prosecuting Attorney of King County or by any person whomsoever by any written form of denial from any sourse whatsoever that the said Nordstrom was insane as claimed by yoru petitioner in behalf of the said Nordstrom.

The the said Hon. Orange, Jacobs, Judge of the Superior Court of the State of Washington for King County did insist upon naming a day for the execution of the said Nordstrom, and did, notwithstanding the h showing and representations, name the 11th day of August, 1899, as the time for taking the life of the said Nordstrom by the sheriff of King County, Washington.

There is no statute in the State of Washington prescribing offence of murder in the first degree and murder in the second degree. That the verdict returned against your petitioner is in words follow- ing, to-wit:
"We, the jury in the above entitled cause wherein the State of Washington is plaintiff and Charles W. Nordstrom is defendant, do find the defendant guilty as charged."

That the said verdict in nowise adjudges your petitioner guilty of murder in the first degree. That said information charged your petitioner with the crime of murder in the second degree two offences; first, with the crime of murder in the first degree; second, with the crime of murder in the second degree. That the said verdict herein finds your petitioner guilty as charged, and but and only charges him with the crime of muder and in nowsie specifiying that they find him guilty of murder in the degree known as first. That under the law no presumption can prevail, save and except a presumption most favoring the petitioner. That the Supreme Court of the State of Washington construed the statute under which your petitioner was tried and declared the law of the State of Washington tobe that a killing proved created the presumption of murder in the second degree. That there must be an especial finding of murder in the first degree to justify the presumption of the existence of such. That the absence of any statement or finding of any jury against your petitioner other then as herein stated no other nor futher nor greater offence has been adjudged against him than that of murder in the second degree. That the punishment for murder in the second degree is imprisionment in the penitenitary of the State of Washington exceeding twenty years, and in nowise is there law or authority for the taking of the life of your petitoner, or any other person upon such verdict as herein reported and returned upon such information as herein stated and filed against your petitioner.
That any attempt to take the life of your petitioner at this time is in violation,

First, of the Constitution of the United States providing and pre- scribing and granting due process of law, to-wit, a full and complete hearing upon all the issues raised by the petitioner, among which, your petitioner's condition of mind, that is, to-wit, his insanity, and his right to be exempt from execution while in such condition.

Second, Is in direct violation of the statutes of the United States and the law of the United States prescribing that all process of any State or any State Court shall be null and void while any pro- ceeding is pending either upon appeal or on Habeas Corpus before a Federal Court of the United States.

Third, Because the same is contrary to the Constitution of the United States, is contrary to the laws of the United States, and is without any jurisdiction in the State Court of this or any other State, and in violation of the rights of your petitioner as a citizen of the United States and entitled to the protection oof the laws of the United States and Constitution of the same.

W H E R E F O R E, Petitioner prays that Your Honor will grant unto your petitioner a Writ of Habeas Corpus commanding your petitioner to be brought before this court at such time and place as the court shall deem convenient, whereat the court could inquire of the matters and things alleged by your petitioner, and that Your Honor would issue a Writ of Certiorari to the Superior Court of the State of Washington for King County ordering to be duly certified to the court the records of this said cuase for information, that Your Honor may beinformed of the premises, and that upon such record and upon such hearing of the cause such further and other order may be made as in the premises will be right and proper.
And your petitioner will ever pray.
County of K i n g )

J. HENRY DENNIN, being first duly sworn, on oath d eposes and says: That he is the friend of the petitioner named herein, Charles W. Nordstrom, that he knows the matters and things set forth in the petition, and of the matters of his own knowledge says they are true, and the other mattres of law he is advised thatthey are true and therefore believes the wole of said petition to be true.
Subscribed and swron to before me this 29 day of July, A.D. 1899.
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON,

I, John F. Miller, prosecuting attorney for King County, State of Washington, come now here and give the xourt to understand and be in- formed and on oath de accuse Charles W. Nordstrom by this information of the crime of murder in the first degree, as follows:

He, the said Charles W. Nordstrom, in said King County, State of Washington, on the 27th day of November 1891, purposely, and of his deliberate and premediatated malice, killed Wiliam Mason, by then and there purposely, and of his deliberate and premediated malice, shooting and mortally wounding the said William Mason, with a gun which he, the said Charles W. Nordstrom, then and there held in his hands.
Dated at Seattle, in said County of King aforesaid, the 8th day of December 1891.
County of K i n g )

John F. Miller, being first duly sworn, deposes and states that he is the prosecuting attorney of King County, State of Washing- ton, that he has read the foregoing information, and that the allega- tions and statements made therein are true as alleged.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 8th day of December 1891.
Clerk of the Superior Court, King County, Washington,
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON FOR KING COUNTY.
IN THE MATTER OF THE APPLICATION OF CHARLES W. NORDSTROM FOR RELIEF FROM CONDITION OF INSANITY
-vs- A F F I D A V I T.

James Hamilton Lewis, being first duly sworn, on oath deposes and says: That for record of the preceeding in the said matter above named and for a record of the recitals of all the facts connected therewith, the following is a true and absolute statement is a complete, full and true exemplification, exhibition, and statement of the whole record of transaction in connection with the proceeding. That all matter of every nature whatsoever that is now or has been a part of any record or of any proceeding in so far as the same has been made known in anywise whatsoever is herin stated, provided, except only such record as the trnacript of the Clerk of the Superior Court of this County has disclosed anterior to the datte of this affidavit. That on the day of A.D. 1899, at the City of Seattle, King County, Washington, Charles W. Nordstro, was duly charged upon affidavit by J. Henry Denning, a legally qualified dependent, and due suggestion and statement by motion based upon said affidavit was also propertly made and duly filed, duly reciting and regularly stated charged the said Nordstrom of being non compos mentis ; that said Nordstrom was of insane mind and un- able to appreciate his surroundings, had no knowledge sufficient to conduct his affairs, or understand or appreciate the extent or nature or consequence of any proceeding being had or taken against or for him or in which he was interested. That this deponent, as counsel for the said Nordstrom, duly moved the Court for such proper proceeding looking to the ascertainment of the mental state of the said Nordstrom, based upon and supported by the said affidavit and charge of insanity, also that such other course be had and taken by which judgment appropriate to the proceeding and further proceedings consistent with the facts elicited to be had. That thereupon the Court, in the presece of the Counsel for the State, representing the County of King, and appearing as opposing the motion for inquiry into the lunacy of the said Nordstrom; and said Court stated that he would name a Commission to examine into the subject at a future day named, to-wit: the day of 18999; that thereupon this affiiant as counsel for defendant arose and stated to the Court that, in so far as the selection of a Commission for a preliminary inquiry, the commissioners being scinentific men, was concerned, affiant favoured proceedings to that extent, but must not be understood as consenting to the intimation given out that said Commission could take upon themselves the right to pass upon the question, or to proceed for or against the defendant of their own volition as a court or trial body That affiant felt it his duty to inform the Court then and there that nothing could be done carrying with it the idea that affiant was waiving such rights as defedant would have, or was sitting in acquiescence to the course of proceeding without taking the due course of informing the Court as to what he thought, as counsel for the defendant and an advuser of the Court, was proper and just in the premises, either as to the course of proceeding or the course of procedure.

That on the day of , 1899, affiant being present as a friend of the defendant, Assistant Prosecuting Attorney, John B. Hart, being present representing the State, Hon. Orange Jacobs, the presiding Judge in the presence of affiant and said Assistant

Prosecuting Attorney, John B. Hart, stated that he had agreed upon a Commission of physicians consisting of five gentlemen, being medical men, to-wit: Drs. C.V. Calhoun, Rufus S. Willard, A.B. Marion, Emil Bories, and the phsician attendin in the Insane Asylum at Steilacom; that he had concluded upon the commission without taking the suggestions of either the said Nordstrom or his friend or any one in his behalf, or of the state or any one in its behalf. Affiant then publicly state that he presumed that he would be given notice when the said commission would be returnable whereupon and at which time he assured he would be given opportunity to present what he thought and understood under the law were the rights of the said Nordstrom; That affiant then and there understoof the court specifically to say to the said Assistant Prosecuting Attorney that he should prepare such proper order naming the day of the citation and serve the same upon affiant, and understood the said Assistant Pros- ecuting Attorney to assert that he would do such; and this affiant then and there relying upon service of notice upon him of some kind or in some form of the meeting of said commission by which he would be given due opportunity of presenting the rights of the said Nordstrom, and such other motion or suggestions as to affiant would appear right, just as proper in the premises. That subsequently, to-wit, on the day of 1899, the said Hon. John B. Hart, Assistant Prosecuting Attorney in open court upon this affiant making public statement to the Court that upon that statement of the Court, he had been led to believe that he was to have notice, by reason of said statements of the Court to the said Assistant Prosecuting Attorney, she said Hon. John B. Hart stated that he did not so understand the Court or that he did not hear the Court make such statement, and affiant states that in this opinion of the said Hon. John B. Hart, and the said Prosecuting Attorney's office representing the state in opposing the proceeding, were sincere in their statemet thaht they did not hear the court and did not so under- stand the court, and affiant begs to state that he under no consider- ation either directly or indirectly asserts that the said Assistant Prosecuting Attorney, Hon? John B. Hart, the Prosecuting Attorney or any of his assistants or deputies, purpsely violated the order of the Court or attempted to evade any duty to the Court that was incum- bent upon them. That from said date up to and including Saturday morning 10 o'clock of the 6th day of May, 1899, when this affiant made his oral protest against the proceedng which he had understoof had transpired there had been in nowise whatsoever, directly or indi- rectly, served upon the said Nordstrom, upon this said affiant, or J. Henry Denning, or any other person whomsoever, any notice of any proceeding, or the time fo any proceeding, or the occasion of any action, or the presence, or the citing of any commission, or of any proceeding whatsoever in anywise whatsoever connected with or con- cerning or relating to, the commission or alleged inquiry into the condition of the said Nordstrom, or as to the proceedings or course of any alleged commission or body of persons, or of any proceeding of any nature whatsoever in anywise whatsoever. That affiant as a friend of the said Nordstro observed from the public press, the only form of notice or information of any whatsoever; first appearing in the Seattle Daily Times the following article:
Judge Jacobs Appoints the Commission to
Examine into the Sanity of Nordstrom.

udge Jacobs to day announced the names of the members of the medical commission appointed for the purpose of examining into the sanity of Charles W. Nordstrom, the condemned murderer of Willie Mason The commission is composed of Dr. F. L. Godard, Superintendent of the Western Washington Insane Hospital for the Insane; Dr. C.V. Calhoun, Dr. A.N. Marion, Dr. Emil Bories and Dr. Rufus Willard. Court were instructed to resent in

"We have made a very careful examination of the prisoner and taken the testimony of the sheriffs and other officers in whose custody and under whose observation the said Charles W. Nordstrom has been since his incarceration, and we are of the unanimous opinion that he is now in such a condition of mind as to be able to distinguish between right and wrong. And as far as we have been able to ascertain there has been no material change in his mental condition since his conviction."

Nordstrom, in charge of a deputy sheriff, sat inside the rail when the fice commissioners, through their foreman, presented their report. Through the reading he listened with attention and appeared to smile sardonically. Possibly it was only a nevous twitching of the muscels of his face. He refused to talk to any one in the court room or later in his cell down in the jail.

the verdict of the commission was a suprise to many persons, even those familiar with Nordstrom's case. While most of the latter were not inclined to believe Nordstrom insane, they were equally unprepared to announce him thoroughly sane, and it was the general opinion among them that the commissioners would disagree or report Nordstrom mentally unballaced.

The commissioner's verdict will be final with Judge Jacobs. as he publicly stated that he would abide by the result of the examination and sentence or not sentence the prisoner to death, according to whether the commission reported him sane or insane.

That intermediate form the publication of one article to the other affiant nor the said Nordstrom or this affiant, or any person or persons whomsoever acting in behalf of the said Nordstrom in any capacity whatsoever, received any notice whatsoever of any proceeding, or opportunity given in anywise whatsoever for the protection of the rights, interest, or cause of the said Nordstrom, or to bebeheard by witnesses or by counsel or by friend, or to be present to cross-examine or opporunity to protext the rights of the said Nordstrom against others whose interests are adverse to the claims of the said Nordstrom or the clients of his friends. And the said Hon. Orange Jacobs, before whom this affiant made oral protest against the proceedings and the treatment of the said Nordstrom in the premises, stated that he had chosen said commission and instructed them ti investigate the question of the sanity of the said Nordstrom, by look- ing exclusively and solely to the single standard of whether the said Nordstrom was able to distinguish right from wrong, and if so, to report such fact to him. That he the said Judge prohibited the commission from being visited or attended by any one representing said Nordstrom either as counsel or friend, likewise prohibiting the attendance on said commission by any one representing the state in anywise whatsoever; affiant says that the said commission was authorized to take such procedure as they thought proper and in such maner as they chose, no person being allowed to suggest testmony in behalf of the said Nordstrom, nor to aypear and cross-examine, or to elicit before the said commission either the prejudice, bias, competency, incom- petency, qualification or disqualificatio of any witess or their interests who did so testify against the said Nordstrom and his claims. Affiant states that it was his opinion and understanding gathered from the law and the doctrines therein announced that the office of the commission was to inquire and possess themselves of cert- tain facts and to qualify themselves as experts and that thereafter they were to appeard at such proper time and under such proper circum- stances to give their testimony either before the court in a judicial inquiry or a jury in a hearing or trial and their opinion, which opinio together with the testimony upon which it was based being also before the court or a jury, and there submitted to the ordinary test permitted by the law, and ordinary cross-examination and inveti- gation under the rules and standards justified by the law, and said court or jury would have seached their conclusions under the ordin- ary procedure upon an ordinary tried or ordinary hearing in which the life or interests of a person were involved would have been conducted. That whatever testimony was had by the commission and the nature of it or the facts elicited, or the course of their procedure, or the con- uct of their inquiry being in nowise reported or preserved or know, it is impossible that the same could be the subject of review, or re- vision, investgation, or correction by any Judge or of any appellate court or tribunal, which according to the rights or interests of any person interested or involved in said proceeding should have been accessuble and of existence, affiant therefore is unable to state more fully the facts of any inquiry whatsoever or any proceeding whatsoever conducted by said commission or any part of the same, of which affiant will only state his opinion that the said commission understood that their duty was that, however, insane defendant might have appeared, however unfit for the excecution or the due discharge of any obligation, however wanting in moral senses and blunted intellegence, it was enough if by the inquiry they could ascertain if he knew right from wrong on any subject, that then and there such ascertain,ent ended their duty, and that alone became the subject of their recommendation. That the tests or course which said commission took in discharging their instructions and duties in order to ascertain whether the defendant knew right from wron, or what basis they used as a base of right, or what basis they used as a base of wrong, whether one recognized by the law, or any recogized by modern science and the law, or whether one which would have been permissible had it been submitted to a judicial tri- bunal, and affiant is unable to state and is unable to inform the court because of the utter failture and complete abscence of all record of the proceedings, and becase of the utter refusal neglect of the said commission to make any any proceeding of record in anywise whatsoever accessible to the said Nrdstrom or his friends or coun- sel. That thereafter, to-wt, on the 5 day of May, 1899, the said commission assuing to act as such, returned into court a certain alleged finding, commonly called a verdict, of their judgment as to the said Nordstrom, which is in words and language as follows. to-wit: To the Hon. Orange Jacobs, Judge of the Superior Court:

Your commission, appointed to examine Charles W. Nordstrom, a prisoner now confined in the county jail under sentence of death, and report his mental condition to this honorable court, has performed that duty and beg to report as follows:

We have made a very careful examination of the prisoner and taken the testimony of the sherrifs and other officers in whose custody and under whose observation the said Charles W. Nordstrom has been since his incarceration, and we are of the unanimous opinion that he is now is such a condition of mind as to be able to distinhuish between right and wrong. And as far as we have been able to ascertain there has been no material change in his mental condition since his conviction.

That the said alleged verdict and judgment in nowise finds any fact either of the sanity of insanity of the said Nordstrom, or any other fact whatsoeverwhich can be recognized or is in conformity to the law as a legal finding upon any issue which in law could be legally recognized by any tribunal recognized by the law. That there has never been at any time any hearing or inquiry upon the charge on non campos mentis or insanity only made against or in behalf of the said Nordstrom in anywise whatsoever, and at this hour and at this time said charge so duly made remains undisposed of without investigation conclusion or judgment in anywise whatsoever.

That this affidavit is made in order that some record of the proceeding while now on the memory of persons interested may be preserved, to the end that the rights of the said Nordstrom may be duly protected by such proper legal course and procedure as under the Constitution and laws of the United States and the State of Washing- ton would be just in the premises. That affidavit particularly wishes to impose upon the court, or any appellate court, that speaking as the friend of said Nordstrom, he desires to conve unequivocally the impression and information that the said Hon. Orange Jacobs in whatsoever course or action he took in the premises was animated and influenced by what he belives to be the highest sense of his duty and was a justifyable proceeding, and one which he believed shuld be duly guarded by the law and proper notice in the premiss as was incumbent upon The State

That affiant states it to be his opinion and belief that the mistake and injustices which has arisen to the said Nordstrom and which has grown out of this proceeding as theu now exist have been brought about by an unfortunate misunderstanding, in that the court presumed that the Prosecuting Attorney would give due notice to the said Nordstrom and his friend and counsel in order that his right as understood by him, would be duly urged at the proper time, and that the said Prosecuting Attorney misunderstood, or not com- prehending the court in that direction, failed to understand that such was the desire of the court or that such was the duty of the Prosecuting Attorney, and no notice whatsoever of any proceeding, what- soever was given, and no notice of any proceeding whatsoever was permitted or allowed or in anywise transpitred by which the said Nordstrom's interests could have been presented, guarded or protected. That affiant would have ventured ti appear before the court had he known at what time the commission itended to sit or have a hearing. That affiant had lately returned from the East and had great press of business affairs upon him and did not have opportunity or occassion to go at all hours to the cour house and ascertain by investigation whether any proceedings have been taken or not, particu- larly, is this true in view of affiant's natural expectation that due and proper notice would be given the said Nordstrom or his friend and counsel.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 10th day of May, A.D. 1899.
Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
Murderer Nordstrom Before an Insanity Commission
"Their Finding will Determine whether he shall Die or go to the Asylum.

The commission appointed by Judge Jacobs for the purpose of determining whether or not Murderer Charles W. Nordstrom is insane began its itttings this afternoon. The commission is composed of Dr. F.L. Goddard, superintendent of that Western Washington Hospital for the insane: Dr. A.N. Marion, Dr. G.V. Calhoun, Dr. Emil Bories, Dr. Rufus Willard. Dr. Calhoun was appointed Foreman of the commission.

Before the commission began its session Judge Jacobs delivered an impressive charge to its members. He recited the authority under the law by virtue of which the commission was appointed; defined insanity as contemplated by the law as being a condition of mind un- able to distinguish between right and wring, and charged the members of the commission to investigate ever particle obtainable evidence which would throw light on the question oe whether or not Nordstrom has become insane since his confinement in the County Jail.

Judge Jacobs laid particular stress upon the responsibility that devolved upon the members of the commission, stating that the destiny of the condemned man rested upon their finding in his case The law, he saidm did not contemplate the excecution of an idiot or maniac, but it was the duty of the commission to determine by every scientific test known to the medical profession whether or not the prisoner is in a state of mind to recognize his condition and his impending doom.

At a late hour this afternoon the commission had not yet bagan to examine witnesses, the time being occupied in discussing a mode of procedure. It is likely that one of the first witnesses will be Ex-county Jailer Munroe, who was in charge of the County Jail at the time Nordstrom was first confined. He will testify to Nordstrom's consition at that time.

The sessions of the commission will be held in Judge Jacobs' private office in his chambers, and every one is denied admittance to the room except the members of the commission and the prisoner. Even the deputy sheriff must remain in the ante-room within call."
United States Circuit Court for the District of Washington.
In the application of Charles W. Nordstrom for a Writ of Habeas Corpus by
his next friend J. Henry Denning.
To the Clerk of the above Entitled Court:
You will please enter my appearance as attorney for pettioned in the above entitled cause
Notice--Attorneys will please endorse their own Filings. Rule 47.
In the application of Charles W. Nordstrom
IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON,
In the Matter of the Application of Charles W. Nordstrom for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, Appearing by his next, Friend, J. Henry Denning.

This cause coming on for hearing upon the petition of petitioners for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, the court, being advised upon the petition and upon hearing counsel for the peitioner, denies and refuses to grant the said Writ; to which ruling of the court petitioner excepts. Exeption allowed.

Petitioner thereupon gives notice that he appeals from the said ruling of the court and from the whole and every part thereof and appeals his said petition and his said cause and the whole and each and every part thereof to the Supreme Court of the United States, holding terms at the City of Washington, District of Columbia, and to the next regulat term thereof, and particularly appeals from the said ruling of the said court denying and refusing to grant the said Writ of Habeas Courpus.
Which said appeal is here and now allowed. Done in open court this 29th of July, 1899.
In the Circuit Court of the UNITED STATES
In the application of Charles W. Nordstrom for a Writ of Habeas Corpus by his next friend, J. Henry Denning,
Filed this 29th day of July 1899 A Reeves Ayres Clerk. By HM Walthew Deputy
Corner First Ave. and James St. SEATTLE, WASH.
IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON,
In the Matter of the Application of Charles W. Nordstrom for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, Appearing by his next, Friend, J. Henry Denning.
To the State of Washington, and to A.T. Van de Vanter, Sheriff of King County, State of Washington, and to Hon James F. McElroy,

Comes, now the petitioner, Charles W. Nordstrom, by his next friend, J. Henry Denning, and appeals the above entitled cause and the whole thereof to the Supreme Court of the United States, holding terms at the City of Washington, District of Columbio, and to the next regular term thereof, and more especially appeals from that certain order made and entered in the above entitled cause on the 29 day of July, 1899, by the Honorable C. H. Hanford, Judge, sitting as the Circuit Court, denying the petition of petitioner for a Writ of Habeas Corpus and refusing to grant the said Writ of Habeas Corpus as in his said petition prayed.

And you will take notice that the record and proceedings upon the said petition will be duly certified through the said above entitled court to the said Supreme Court of the United States at the next regular term thereof upon said named appeal.

M. ASHLEY, being first duly sworn, on oath deposes and says: That at all the times herein and hereafter mentioned, I was, and am now, a citizen of the United States of America, and of the District of Washington, and a resident of King County, in said District of Washington, above the age of twenty-one (21) years.

That at Seattle, King County, State of Washington, on the 31st day of July, A.D. 1899, I duly served the within Notice of Appeal together with a duly certified copy f the order allowing the affiant foreing M.A. J.H.D. upon A. T. Van de Vanter, sheriff of King County, State of Washington, he being the respondent and appellee in said within Notice of Appeal named, by delivering to and leaving with the said A.T. Van de Vanter, sheriff of King County, State if Washington, a true copy of said within Notice of Appeal and a duly certified copy of said order allowing M.A. J.H.D. said appeal.

That at Seattle, King County, State of Washington, on the 31stt day of July, A.D. 1899, I duly served the within Notice of Appeal, together with a duly certfied copy of the order allowing the appeal herein, M.A.J.H.D upon James F. McElroy, Prosecuting Attorney for King County, State of Washington, on behafl of the said State of Washington, the State of Washington beng the respondent and appellee insaid within Notice of Appeal named, by delivering to and leaving with said James F. McElroy, Esq., Prosecuting Attorney for King County, State of Washington, a true copy of said within Notice of Appeal and a duly certified copy of said order M.A.J.H.D allowing said appeal.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 31st day of July, A.D. 1899.
J Henry Dening Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.

United States Circuit Court District of Washington.
In the application of Charles W. Nordstrom for Habeas Corpus etc.,
IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON,
In the Matter of the Application of Charles W. Nordstrom for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, Appearing by his next, Friend, J. Henry Denning.
N O T I C E.
To the Hon. A. T. Van de Vanter, sherif of King County, State of Washington:
You will please take notice hereby that Charles W. Nordstrom, now in your custody, duly petitioned the Circuit Court of the United States for a Writ of Habeas Corpus seeking relief thereunder, and,
Whereas, the said writ and relief was denied, and
Whereas, said petitioner duly moved for the right of appeal and for the transfer of his whole cause to the Supreme Court of the United States, and

Whereas, the said cause came on for argument as to the granting of the said appeal and the transfer of the whole cause to the appellate Court, and was heard upon the 29th day of Juy 1899, by the Hon. C. H. Hanford, Circuit Judge, and,

Whereas, after hearing said application, an order of appeal was duly granted, and the said cause was so ordered transferred to the Supreme Court of the United States, a full copy of said proceedings ad the order allowing said appeal, being duly certified, is hereunto annexed for your information and advice.

And, whereas, under the Revised Statutes of the United States, being the law of the United States, particularly, Section 766 of the said Revised Statutes of the United States, reads as follows, to-wit:

Sec. 766 "Pending the proceedings on appeal in the cases mentioned in the three preceding section, and until final judg- ment therein, and after final judgment of discharge, any proceedings against the person so imprisioned or confined or restrained of his liberty, in any State Court, or by or under the authority of any State, for any matter so heard and determined, under such writ of Habeas Corpus, shall be deemed null and void."

And whereas, the Supreme Court of the United States In Re Jugiro 140 U. S. 295, construing the said section, defined the same to mean "in cases where the applicant was held in custody under the authority of a state court or by the authority of a State to stay the hands of such court or State while the question as to whether his detention was in violation of the Constitution, laws or treaties of the United States was being examined by the courts of the United States having jurisdiction in the premises;" which sad decision is more fully referred to in the case on In Re M'Kane, 61 Fed. 205, where it was held to mean that until final decision in the Supreme Court f the United States no disturbance of the condition of the prisoner as he was at the time of the denying of the writ can be in anywise had:

Therefore youa re hereby notified that you are to hold posession or custody of the said petitioner, Charles W. Nordstrom, now in your keeping at the City of Seattle, County of King, State of Washington, in such manner as to your discretion shall seem meet and proper, in nowise assuming for any cause to execute any sentence of death whatsoever upon the said petitioner, Charles W. Nordstrom, and you will be duly notified of any other proceedings in the premises.
You will please govern yourself accordingly.
Jas. Hamilton Lewis Attorney for Petitioner.
United States of America, ) District of Washington, :ss C o u n t y of K i n g. )

M. ASHLEY, being first duly sworn, on oath deposes and says: That at all the times herein and hereafter mentioned, I was, and am now, a citizen of the United States of America, and of the District of Washington, and a resident of King County, in said District of Washington, above the age of twenty-one (21) years.

That at Seattle, King County, State of Washington, on the 31st day of July, A.D. 1899, I duly served the within Notice upon A. T. Van de Vater, Sheriff of King County, State of Washington, he being the respondent and appellee in said within Notice named, by delivering to and leaving with said A. D. Van de Vater, Sheriff of King County, State of Washington, a true copy of said within Notice.

That at Seattle, King County, State of Washington, on the 31st day of July, A. D. 1899, I duly served the within Notice upon James F. McElroy, Es., Prosecuting Attorney for King County, State of Washing- ton, on behalf of the State of Washington, said State of Washington being the respondent and appellee in said within Notice named, by Prosecuting Attorney for King County, State of Washington, a true copy of said within notice.
Subscried and sworn to before me this 32st dau of July, A.D. 1899.
J Henry Denning Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
IN THE CIRCUIT COURT OF THE UNITED STATES, DISTRICT OF
In the Matter of the Application of Charles W. Nordstrom for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, Appearing by his next, Friend, J. Henry Denning.
Comes now the petitioner and assigns as error committed by the Court in the above entitled cause at the time of the hearing of the same, as follows:
That the Court erred in declining and refusing to issue the Writ of Habeas Corpus upon the record of the above named cause.
That the Court erred in refusing to issue an order to show cause why the Writ should not issue in the above named cause.
That the Court erred ub refusing to make an order restraining proceedings pending the hearing of the Petition for the Writ of Habeas Corpus in the above named cause.
James Hamilton Lewis Attorney for the Petitioner.
In The matter of the application of Charles W. Nordstrom for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, appearing by his next friend J Henry Denning

Received copy of the within and service of the same admitted this day of 189 Attorney for
The President of the United States of America,
To the Honorable the Judges of the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Washington

Whereas, lately in the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Washington, before you or some of you, in a cause entitled In the matter of the application of Charles W. Nordstrom for a writ of habeas corpus, appearing by his next friend, J Henry Denning, No. 784, wherein the order of the said Circuit Court, entered in said cause on the 29th day of July, A.D. 1899, is in the following words, viz;
"In the Circuit Court of the United States, District of Wash- ington, Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Application of CHARLES W. NORDSTROM for a Writ of Habeas Corpus, Appearing by His Next Friend, J. Henry Denning. No. 784. Order.

This cause coming on for hearing upon the petition of petitioner for a writ of habeas corpus, the court, being advised upon the peti- tion and upon hearing counsel for petitioner, deies and refuses to grant the said writ; to which ruling of the court petitioner excepts. Exception allowed.

Petitioner thereupon gives notice that he appeals from the said ruling of the court and from the whole and every part thereof and appeals his said petition and his said cause and the whole and each and every part thereof to the Supreme Court of the United States, holding terms at the city of Washington, District of Columbia, and to the next regular term thereof, and particularly appeals from the said ruling of the said court denying and refusing to grant the said writ of habeas corpus.
Which said appeal is here and now allowed. Done in open court this 29th day of July, 1899.

as by the inspection of the trancript of the record of the said Circuit Court, which was brought into the SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES by the virtue of an appeal taken by Charles W. Nordstrom (by his next friend J. Henry Denning), whereon A. T. Van de Vanter, Sheriff of King County, Washington, and the State of Washington were made the parties appellees agreeably to the act of Congress, in such case made and provided, fully and at large appears.

And whereas, in the present term of October, in the year of our Lord one thousand nine hundred the said cause came on to be heard before the said SUPREME COURT, on the said transcript of record, and o motions to dismiss or affirm which were argued bu counsel;

On consideration whereof, It is now here ordered, adjudged, and decreed by this Court that the order, of the said Circuit Court in this cause be, and the same is hereby, affirmed, with costs; And that the said A. T. Van de Vanter, Sheriff, and The State of Washington recover against the said Charles W. Nordstrom, (by his next friend J. Henry Denning), Eighty four dollars and fifty cents for their costs herein expended and have exceution therefor. May 13, 1901.

You, therefore, are hereby commanded that such execution and proceedings be had in said cause, as according to right and justice, and the laws of the United States, ought to be had, the said appeal notwithstanding.
Witness the Honorable Melville W. Fuller, Chief of Justice of the United States, the 31st day of May, in the year of our Lord one thousand nine hundred and one COSTS of Van de Vanter, Sheriff, et al.
Clerk of the Supreme Court of the United States.
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
Charles W. Nordstrom (by his next friend J. Henry Denning),
A. T. Van de Vanter, Sheriff re., et al.
FILED IN THE U. S. Circuit Court, DIST. OF WASHINGTON
SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES OCTOBER TERM 1900
